span.p: Bismarck Public Schools is continuing to monitor the spread of COVID-19, more commonly known as Coronavirus. We are in regular contact with local and state health officials, as well as other local school districts and colleges, and we are taking direction from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

div.p: Attention all Star Wars fans! Because we all need a good belly laugh about now, check out this Bismarck High video homework assignment by student Emily Stoneciper and her family completed for BHS band director Bob Peske: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1f-R7WIkLAIeS_Pk0PRMVfOWQIIHpH9TK/view?ts=5e98a337

ul.li:
BPS adds Legacy as Food Site: We will add Legacy High as a meal pick up location tomorrow Wed. April 22, from 11:30-12:30 at the front door; updated schedule. Reminder that meals are for ANY child age 1-18 regardless of income. 4,300 meals served today!
Food Containers: If you get food items from BPS that come in plastic containers, DO NOT USE THOSE TO MICROWAVE FOOD IN AS THEY ARE NOT MICROWAVE SAFE. Instead, place items in a microwave safe bowl.

Bank of ND: Its College SAVE 529 plan is sponsoring the EVERFI National Financial Bee-- a first-of-its-kind nationwide financial literacy challenge for students in grades 7-12. To participate, students may complete five 15-minute modules before April 30. Upon completion of the modules, they can submit a 300- to 500-word essay highlighting what they learned. This qualifies students in grades 7-10 with an opportunity to win an EVERFI scholarship of $10,000, $6,000 or $4,000. North Dakota students in grades 7-12 also have the opportunity to receive one of two $529 scholarships from the College SAVE 529 plan. Students can visit nd.gov/financialbee to get started!

strong.u: Facebook Fundraiser for Food Gift Cards:

li.span: Hatch Realty in Bismarck is doing a Facebook fundraiser to provide food gift cards to families in need. To donate, go to

ul.li: Food Collection: The Freedom Riders Motorcycle Club will collect nonperishables, hamburger, and household items for local food pantries on Friday, April 24, from 12-6 pm. The public can drop off donated items at the parking lots at Bismarck High, Century High, Centennial Elementary, Solheim Elementary, Gee Williquors, and both Cash Wise grocery stores.
Larks Baseball: The Larks are hosting a Teacher of the Year contest. Nominate your favorite educator by May 1. For more information go to District Announcements at https://www.bismarckschools.org/

Towel Drive: Buy a towel set to help families in the Students in Transition homeless program. Choose a business to buy from (links below) & have them sent to Sherrice Roness, SIT Coordinator, 806 N. Washington St., Bismarck, ND 58501. This fundraiser is organized by Michelle Ragan, BPS, & Becky Reidinger, U-Mary, as part of the Women’s Leadership Program through the ND Women’s Business Center. Please do not drop off towel sets in person. Thanks for your support!
Target: http://www.target.com/gift-registry/gift/SITTowelDrive
Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/hz/wishlist/ls/1IDDUN99BF37O?ref_=wl_share
Walmart: www.walmart.com/lists/view-events-registry-items?id=48fe13a3-92d7-49bb-87e4-a7f73c830723

div.p: “Kids will remember how we responded and connected during this time more than they will remember everything they learned online.”

ul.li: Applebee’s & BPSF Fundraiser: The response to the Applebee’s fundraiser for BPS families has been FANTASTIC! That said, BOTH locations are participating today. Please submit orders BY PHONE (not online) and mention this fundraiser to ensure an accurate estimate of when your food will be ready for pick up. Thanks for supporting the BPS Foundation and our families in need!

Backpacks of Food for Kids: these will again be available for pick up tomorrow at our to-go meal sites listed and times listed under District Announcements at https://www.bismarckschools.org/. Today, BPS served 4,056 meals!

Go for a Drive Friday Night: To honor the all BPS seniors in the Class of 2020, the Starion softball field will be lit up Friday from 9-9:20 pm at the Sanford Sports Complex in NE Bismarck near Legacy High School. Next Friday, April 24, the lights will be on at the same time and place but at the Dakota Community Bank & Trust stadium. The following Friday, May 1, the 1st International Bank & Trust baseball field at the Sanford Complex will be lit up. Take a drive; check it out!

Great American Bike Race: This year, GABR is doing a virtual event to raise funds for kids and young adults who live with cerebral palsy and other childhood-onset conditions that permanently affect their development. On Saturday, April 25, you can join the 20 for $20 challenge. Do a video of yourself “cycling” for 20 seconds and upload it on your social media. Then tag the GABR Facebook page and ask 5 people you know to pledge $20. More info on how to do this at GABR Event Page and GABR Facebook Event Page
Larks Baseball: The Larks are hosting a Teacher of the Year contest. Nominate your favorite educator by May 1. For more information go to District Announcements at https://www.bismarckschools.org/

Library Book Pilot Project: a big THANK YOU to Dan’s Supermarket for donating 1,000 plastic bags to help with a pilot project of curbside library book delivery. Students at five BPS elementary schools are able to place holds on books online and pick them up curbside at their schools!
North Dakota COVID-19 Community Impact Survey: please take a few minutes to complete this survey from the ND Department of Commerce: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/NDCOVIDCommunityImpact

TV Show of the Day: Tonight at 7 pm on ABC (cable channel 8), there’s a show called Disney Family Singalong that might be fun for the whole family to watch…and sing along, of course! Enjoy your time together.

div.p: If you want to take a break from the negative news & see some good news, Like Us on Facebook or Follow Us on Twitter. Bismarck Public Schools is sharing some great stories!

ul.li: BPS Foundation & Applebee’s: BPSF has partnered with Applebee’s to “take out” the devastating effects of COVID-19 on our struggling families. Proceeds from take-out food purchases TODAY, tomorrow &/or Thursday (11 am-10 pm) will be donated to the BPSF Family Assistance Fund. Locations listed at https://www.bpsfoundation.com/events/takeoutcovid-19/

Child Care for local lifeline workers: Thanks to the Bismarck Parks and Recreation District and Central Regional Education Association for offering emergency childcare to K-5 children of local lifeline workers. The list of who qualifies, costs, staffing, hours of operation, registration, and safety measures can be found at bisparks.org or contact RaNae Jochim, 222-6766, rjochim@bisparks.org with questions.

School Board Meeting Brief: The Bismarck School Board last night heard an update on distance learning. Curriculum staff, instructional coaches, library media specialists, and tech staff are working with teachers to create learning boards for students in grades K-8 to follow to make online learning easier. They look at the standards students need to attain by the end of the year. High school students also must complete standards and required coursework. The School Board accepted the annual Results of Academic Achievement in Math as Making Reasonable Progress with Exception. That report can be found at https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/401. BPS has won the prestigious 2020 Best Communities for Music Education Award from the NAMM Foundation. This outstanding achievement is given to districts that provide music access and education to all students. The Board also heard updates on the Strategic Plan & Facilities Plan—both of which were put on hold during the onset of COVID-19. The Superintendent is hoping the Strategic Plan will be ready for Board approval by the end of May; the Facilities Plan will be discussed again in 30-45 days. Public forums to give input on the plan were postponed due to the coronavirus.

Spring Sports: The ND High School Activities Association today voted to extend the indefinite suspension of Spring Sports, Winter Basketball State Tournaments and Fine Arts contests. NDHSAA will re-evaluate this on May 1.
Video of the Day: Moses secretary Kristin Meidinger does daily e-announcements to students: https://www.wevideo.com/view/1648762526

div.p: As the long weekend break approaches, we remember what’s important: Family, Friends and Faith. See you Tuesday!

ul.li: Academics: since there is no school Friday or Monday, teachers will be unavailable those days to help with school work. Classes resume Tuesday.
Census 2020: With the 4-day weekend ahead, it’s a good time to complete the Census for your household, if you haven’t already, at https://2020census.gov/.

Child Nutrition:
NO BPS to-go meals tomorrow & Monday: There will be no BPS to-go meals on Good Friday, April 10 & Parent-Teacher Conference Day off Mon., April 13, as well as Possible Storm Make-Up Day Mon., April 27.
Community Food Assistance: There’s a link on our website to other food resources in our community, even on weekends. It’s a District Announcement at https://www.bismarckschools.org/

Employee Performance Reviews: The governor suspended the requirement for school districts to conduct written performance reviews of teachers, principals, and assistant/associate superintendents employed for more than three years, to free up teachers and administrators to focus on distance learning. Supervisors will send instructions to hourly and professional support staff regarding their annual evaluations.
Teachers: The deadline for the BPS Foundation Watts grant is Wednesday, April 15. Apply at https://www.bpsfoundation.com/grants/

Video of the Day: Thanks to KX-TV for this story about an example of how our BPS music teachers are filling the void for students: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MldkqdwXiJs&fbclid=IwAR3vW-l941dnZNnHFwuXTzvSQpsPyZWj3qu4aqEKTMrh2Ec-KvLnJcR5VW8. You can see the entire BHS New Gen choir song here, but watch until the end as the last few photos really tell the story (thanks to BHS head custodian Bruce Brady for taking those pics)… https://www.kxnet.com/news/local-news/bismarck-high-school-choir-goes-virtual/?fbclid=IwAR3DPF3fpXCNYcLR5Mn8g15jyYdEGbyKV-3ZYcxXUaSQ7Y58zLWsw0t1YRw

div.p: 60 degrees today: Woo-hoo! Exercise is a great way to relieve stress, no matter what your age! Bismarck is fortunate to have 80+ miles of trails (thanks Bismarck Parks & Recreation District)! Saying “hi” while maintaining a social distance of 6 feet will put a smile on everyone’s face.

ul.li: Academics: since there is no school Friday or Monday, teachers will be unavailable those days to help with school work. Classes resume Tuesday.

Children ages birth to 3: The Early Intervention program at BECEP is free for children ages birth to 3. It is up and running using virtual visits, virtual evaluations, and telephone calls to support infants and toddlers. Do you know a child who may need help with rolling, sitting, crawling, walking, bottling, feeding, dressing, fine motor skills (like puzzles, blocks, coloring), sensory processing, engaging with others, making eye-contact, bonding, talking, following directions, learning new words, doing pretend play and/or problem solving? You can refer your own child by calling 701-328-8985; ask for Early Intervention.
District Comments & Questions: You can always share a complement, question or concern on the homepage of our website, bottom right: https://www.bismarckschools.org/

Frozen Food Items: Starting tomorrow, BPS will send frozen items that can be cooked at home during the daily go-bag distribution (4064 meals served today). Instructions on how to store & heat all items can be found at https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/425

Personal Care Items: Our homeless program liaison is helping to collect personal care items for families in need in our community. This includes things like diapers, wipes, tampons, feminine pads, etc. Pick up/drop off times, dates & locations are listed under District Announcements at https://www.bismarckschools.org/

Video of the Day: Our BPS Foundation & Applebee’s fundraiser set for next week was featured on KFYR TV. Check it out! https://www.kfyrtv.com/content/news/Applebees-partners-with-Bismarck-Public-Schools-to-aid-families-in-need-569426801.html

div.p: From now on, BPS will only send out DISTRICT messages like this one on Tuesdays and Thursdays, unless something important occurs. We know you are getting many emails from schools and teachers now that we have transitioned to distance learning.

ul.li: BPS Foundation & Applebee’s: Our Foundation has partnered with Applebee’s to “take out” the devastating effects of COVID-19 on struggling BPS families. Take-out food purchase proceeds April 13, 14 & 16 at designated Applebee’s locations will be donated to the BPSF Family Assistance Fund. For all the details, go to https://www.bpsfoundation.com/events/takeoutcovid-19/.

Child Nutrition: Starting today, BPS expanded its food distribution sites to 23 total locations and 4,390 meals were served. This means some of the times for some food distribution have changed, so PLEASE review this list of times and locations: NEW SCHEDULE
No BPS meals Friday-Monday: There will be no BPS to-go meals on Good Friday, April 10; Parent-Teacher Conference Day off on Monday, April 13.

Resources for BPS Employees: We have put some COVID-19 information on the Human Resources (HR) webpage, such as symptoms, what to do if you are quarantined, etc. Check it out at https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/3822.

School Board Candidates: Seven people are running for two open seats on the Bismarck School Board. They are Karen Dunlap, Dan Eastgate, Donnell Preskey Hushka, Kristine Johnson, Brooke LeBeau, Nick Thueson & Sargianna Wutzke. Incumbents Heide Delorme & Rick Geloff are not running for re-election June 9.

Video of the Day: Thanks to our student tech intern, Ping, from Century High for creating this video for us to thank all of YOU who send such kind words to our staff during this COVID-10 outbreak: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4R-94M3G7I4

p.em: We hope you have seen us live out our new BPS values these past 3 weeks.

div.p: Innovation: Creating a distance learning plan from the ground up—a HUGE task—which was approved by the state quickly and on the first try!
Leadership: Sharing what we are doing with other school districts in the state.

Excellence: Striving for excellence in all that we do, whether it’s providing to-go meals for families, communicating with all of our stakeholders, cleaning our buses and buildings, getting computers and other school items to students, or personally reaching out to students and families.
Inclusion: Making sure all of our students can participate in the distance learning environment, including those with special needs, English Learners, etc.

ul.li:
Child Nutrition: NEW TIMES, LOCATIONS! Starting Monday, April 6, BPS will expand its food distribution sites to 23 total sites! This means some of the times and locations for food distribution have CHANGED, so PLEASE review this list: NEW SCHEDULE. Meals served today: 3,617.
Monday, April 6 Sandwich: BPS sack lunches will again contain sealed peanut butter & jelly sandwiches on Monday. If you need a peanut-free substitute meal, email Joan Knoll with the child’s name & pick up site.
Special Education: Parents of special needs children are asked to review this document: Contingency Plan Newsletter
To end the week: Check out this cool video produced by Rita Murphy 2nd grade teachers and their students: https://www.wevideo.com/view/1631755785

div.p: Message from Bismarck Education Assoc. President Lori Furaus: BEA message

ul.li:
Child Nutrition: We have added Centennial, Miller, Murphy and Northridge. Other 14 meal sites Monday-Friday, 11:30 am to 12:30 pm are BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Roosevelt, Solheim, Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. Meals served today: 2,453.
FRIDAY, APRIL 3 SANDWICH: BPS sack lunches will contain sealed peanut butter and jelly sandwiches this Friday. If you have been picking up lunch and your child has a peanut allergy, please email Joan Knoll with your child’s name and pick up location. A peanut-free substitute meal will be provided for them.
WEEKEND Food Backpacks: On Fridays, students in need get a food backpack for the weekend at the same sites listed above, 11:30-12:30.
STARTING MONDAY, April 6: BPS will expand its food distribution sites to 23 total locations! This means some of the times for some food distribution have changed, so PLEASE review this list of times and locations to be implemented next week.

Social Media: there are heart-warming stories sent by staff, students and parents each day on our BPS Facebook and Twitter sites, so “Like” or “Follow” Bismarck Public Schools to see these posts and other information. If you have posts to share of the wonderful things our students & staff are doing, please email to Renae Walker.

Wear BLUE tomorrow: On Friday, April 3, please wear blue to support children and families during National Child Abuse Prevention Month. Everyone plays a role in making great childhoods happen! Promoted by Prevent Child Abuse ND and the ND Dept. of Human Services.

div.p: On this April Fools’ Day, we could only wish COVID-19 was a joke. Since it is not, Social School EDU is providing a “Tip of the Day” for 30 days this month to give ideas of what you can do with your children/students to pass the time. It might be a daily incentive to get them to do their schoolwork! These will be posted daily on our BPS Facebook page at noon. April 1: Take a virtual trip on the internet, in a book, or by watching a TV show to a place you’ve always wanted to visit. Then share a cool fact you learned!

ul.li: Superintendent Video Message for 4/1/2020: https://learnbps.bismarckschools.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=18339

Activities: the ND High School Activities Association voted yesterday to extend the suspension of spring sports indefinitely. A decision about ND spring Fine Arts contests and winter basketball tournaments will be made later in April.

li.span: : 4 NEW SITES! Starting tomorrow (Thursday), we are adding Centennial, Miller, Murphy and Northridge. The other 14 meal sites Monday-Friday, 11:30 am to 12:30 pm, are: BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Roosevelt, Solheim, Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. Meals served today: 3,852.

ul.li: FRIDAY, APRIL 3 SANDWICH: BPS sack lunches will contain sealed peanut butter and jelly sandwiches this Friday. If you have been picking up lunch and your child has a peanut allergy, please email BPS dietician Joan Knoll with your child’s name and pick up location. A peanut-free substitute meal will be provided for them.

div.p: BPS uses the 4Cs to educate students: Collaboration, Communication, Critical Thinking, and Creativity. Technology Director Tanna Kincaid says, “Make no mistake. The creativity, critical thinking and collaboration of all of our BPS staff are what has gotten us this far and will take us into the future. Success Skills are the key to problem solving!” Our Community Relations Dept. also has 4Cs: Communicate Clearly and Consistently with Compassion. Take care and have a good rest of your day.

ul.li: Child Care: BPS is working in collaboration with the Bismarck Parks and Recreation District and the Central Regional Education Association (CREA) to establish possible emergency child care in a few K-5 schools if needed for lifeline workers so they can continue to provide essential services to our community.

li.span: : Meal sites Monday-Friday, 11:30 am to 12:30 pm: BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Roosevelt, Solheim Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. Meals served today: 3,532. On Thursday, 4 additional sites will be added so watch for tomorrow’s update.

ul.li: No meals on school days off: There will be no BPS to-go meals on Good Friday, April 10; Parent-Teacher Conference Day off on Monday, April 13; and the Possible Storm Make-Up Day on Monday, April 27.
Community Food Assistance: There’s a link on our website to other food resources in our community. It’s a District Announcement at https://www.bismarckschools.org/

Song to Make You Smile: Our own BPS tech staffer and musician Pat Phillips wrote an original song about the coronavirus. He says, “My 'porch concert' shout out to everyone and all our education friends around the globe: https://twitter.com/i/status/1244287132950302720

Staff Pay Information: Thank you to the Bismarck School Board who today approved paying BPS permanent staff through the end of this school year. BPS employees were sent this information via email from the Human Resources Department. Please read it carefully. If you have questions, contact HR.

div.p: With school starting online, you may want to establish a routine again with your children again, similar to when school starts in the fall! Set a schedule for meals, schoolwork, play, fresh air, reading, talking to friends, and bedtime. Children crave routine; help them create a predictable schedule in this unpredictable time.

ul.li: Academics: Bismarck Public Schools has moved to distance learning for all PreK-12 students for the foreseeable future due to the ongoing spread of COVID-19. BPS schools/facilities are closed. To assist with this effort, BPS this afternoon sent all parents and staff an instructional video and a handbook with helpful information.

Child Nutrition: Starting today, BPS added Solheim & Roosevelt as 2 more school sites for breakfast/lunch to-go bags; 4114 meals were served today. Four more sites are to be added Thursday, so stay tuned! The other sites right now are BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. Meal distribution is Monday-Friday, 11:30 am-12:30 pm.
No meals on school days off: There will be no BPS to-go meals on Good Friday, April 10; Parent-Teacher Conference Day off on Monday, April 13; and the Possible Storm Make-Up Day on Monday, April 27.
Community Food Assistance: There’s a link on our website to other food resources in our community. It’s a District Announcement at https://www.bismarckschools.org/

Chromebook Remote Assistance: BPS is remotely adding the Chrome Remote Desktop utility to student Chromebooks to enable BPS staff to provide remote assistance to students. With the safety of our students in mind, we feel it is important for parents to understand the security of Chrome Remote Desktop. Chromebooks can only be remotely accessed after the student initiates a support request. Chrome Remote Desktop generates a unique, one-time code and the student must share this code with the person providing tech support, such as a teacher, library media specialist, technology department staff, etc. The student will then be prompted to allow access to the support person. All BPS staff can be identified by their @bismarckschools.org email address.

Distance Learning: the orange Distance Learning icon is up and running on the BPS district homepage at https://www.bismarckschools.org/ or on any BPS school We had some technical issues this morning, but hopefully we have those bugs worked out now.

Foundation Grants & Scholarships:
Teachers: The Watts Grant deadline has been extended to April 15. Go to https://www.bpsfoundation.com/grants/ for more information or to apply. Here’s a link for info about all Foundation services to BPS: https://www.bpsfoundation.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/BPS-BPSF-Benefits-19-20.pdf
Seniors: The BPS Foundation student scholarship deadline is extended to May 1. The Foundation website also provides links to other scholarships available through the ND Community Foundation. For information, go to https://www.bpsfoundation.com/scholarships/.

div.p: Introducing Distance Learning:

BPS is excited to announce our distance learning portal. This short video provides a tour of the portal and how to get around. We encourage you to watch so that you know how to access the learning activities and a variety of other supports. https://bit.ly/BPS-DistanceLearning

BPS has also created a Family and Student Handbook. Some of the topics in the handbook are attendance, assessment, learning plans, and health and wellness. Please check it out here https://bit.ly/BPSFamilyHandbook or in the Distance Learning Portal under Help. You can access each section from the middle of the page or the left side.
We are grateful for our students and families. Everyone has shown so much flexibility and perseverance.
Have a great week.

p.span: BPS is excited to announce our distance learning activities are ready for the upcoming week!

span.img: For our PreK-8 students, learning activities will be made public for the week on collective planning documents called “learning boards” accessible through any BPS webpage under the orange Distance Learning Portal icon. Activities are live now so click around and explore. Tomorrow morning you will receive a video screencast and a handbook to further assist in navigating these learning activities.

li.span: can access grade level learning boards online or in printed form from their buildings.
can access learning boards organized by school teams or request printed forms from their buildings.
students will receive direct communication from their teachers and school directories to online classrooms will be posted and updated as they are available.
learning boards will be directly communicated to families by case managers no later than Monday morning.

p.span: If you are in need of a printed version or have specific questions related to the activities, access, or other, please contact your child’s teacher or school directly -
Thank you for joining us in our commitment to ensure quality learning continues, even from a distance!

div.p: ND Superintendent of Schools Baelser and Governor Burgum have approved Bismarck Public School's Distance Learning Plan.

Also, starting Monday, 2 more school sites for breakfast/lunch to-go bags will be added: Solheim & Roosevelt. The other 12 sites are BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS & South Central. Meal distribution is Monday-Friday, 11:30 am-12:30 pm.
Dear Bismarck Public Schools Community,

Bismarck Public Schools has submitted our distance learning plan to the North Dakota Department of Public Instruction and the Governor for approval. While approval of our plan is pending, staff members have prepared to launch the plan next week. Bismarck Public Schools will begin with the plan starting Monday, March 30; moving to full implementation on April 1, 2020.

The submitted plan is located at https://bit.ly/BPSDistanceLearningPlan. BPS will adapt the plan to reflect any changes recommended by the North Dakota Department of Public Instruction. Our plan details how we will meet all state requirements, while continuing to offer the very best educational services and supports for our students and families. A shorter, more concise document for Staff Guidance and a Student/Parent Handbook will be provided for your use very soon.
Some of the specifics addressed include:

ul.li: Communication: How we will communicate about learning plans and how can parents communicate with us?
Attendance: How will student attendance be recorded?
Assessments and Grades: How will student learning and progress be monitored?
Distance Learning Plans and Timelines: What is the chronological overview of distance learning at elementary, middle school, high school, and the Career Academy?
Special Education: How will we service students with IEPs or 504 plans?
Health and Wellness: How can families access support for counseling, mental health, and other services?

div.p: BPS will continue to share details of the plan with all staff, parents, and students. If you have questions that are specific to your child’s distance learning plan or needs, please contact your child’s school via phone or email. Click here for the directory: https://www.bismarckschools.org/phone. For general questions, please submit them through our BPS Comments/Questions form located at the bottom of our district homepage or at this link - https://bit.ly/BPSQuestionForm. Submitted questions will be used for future communication to our community.

Now and in the coming weeks you will have access to more Distance Learning plans and supports through our Distance Learning Portal located in the top navigation bar on our website. We are still working on this, so we greatly appreciate your patience.

Please watch for information coming from the district and your school on next steps. Additionally, Bismarck Public Schools is updating its COVID-19 website daily with information and resources. Please check the site often at https://www.bismarckschools.org/covid-19. I also encourage you to follow us on Facebook/Twitter.

I want to thank the dedicated BPS staff members who have worked tirelessly over the past two weeks to prepare for the drastic change in the way we deliver education. Everyone is working to account for all student needs and meet them at the very highest level. Secondly, thank you to our parents and students for your understanding and grace during this time of school closure and transition. BPS has established a comprehensive plan for delivering academic instruction in the next few weeks; however, it won’t be without its challenges. Thank you in advance for your patience as we move into a new way of educating our nearly 13,500 students. Please take great care of yourself and your loved ones!
Sincerely,

Bismarck Public School District

Academics: BPS will launch distance learning on Monday, March 30. Watch for further details coming tomorrow.

Documents can be uploaded, faxed or e-mailed to the Central Office to complete the process. Registration information is on our website at https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/3785.

Child Nutrition: We served 3,554 total to-go meals today at BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. Meal distribution is Mon.-Fri., 11:30 am-12:30 pm.

Washington St., Bismarck, ND 58501 with “COVID-19” in the memo line. Central Registration: Please continue registering your kindergartners online for the upcoming 2020-2021 school year! Distance Learning:

Staff: Under the orange Distance Learning icon on the BPS website homepage or your school homepage, you will see a place on the left called “Login to LearnBPS to Access Staff Distance Learning Support.” Once activated, this will have resources for online tools, etc. that teachers can access and use with students.

Parents/Students: On the BPS website and all school websites, you will see an orange icon called “Distance Learning.” This is where we will put information on school work in the future. Please become familiar with what’s been posted so far on that page!

Those that wish to donate may do so through the foundation website or by mail. To donate online, go to https://www.bpsfoundation.com/donate/ and click “COVID-19 BPS Family Assistance.” To donate by mail, send checks to the BPS Foundation at 806 N. Washington St., Bismarck, ND 58501 and write “COVID-19” in the memo line. Families seeking assistance are encouraged to reach out to their counselor or social worker who will connect them to established community resources as well as submit requests for funding needs that cannot be met within existing community resources. div.p: A shout out to our school secretaries and principals who are now fielding calls from families and staff. This has taken the burden off Central Office, which helps us do our planning work. We also thank our custodians who are making sure our buildings are functioning and doing cleaning and routine maintenance work. We appreciate you more than you know. Thanks for being the front line folks of our school district right now!

ul.li: Academics: When Governor Burgum says schools will be “closed indefinitely” that doesn’t mean school is out for the year. BPS is taking a week-by-week approach and we will keep you updated on school closures, make up days, etc. So far the Governor has forgiven missing school days through March 31. BPS will also start Distance Learning next week. Elementary teachers will be connecting with their families to provide information, answer questions, etc. Secondary schools may reach out to students/families using a variety of methods, such as individual or Home Base messages, for example.

Child Nutrition: Thanks to many staff and volunteers, we served 3,000+ to-go meals today at 12 sites: BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. This will continue Monday-Friday, 11:30 am-12:30 pm.

Go to your middle school website under District Announcements for instructions. Each elementary principal will communicate with their parents this week regarding getting computers. One will be provided per family if they don’t already have a home computer they can use.

Distance Learning: On the BPS website & all school websites, you will now see an orange icon called “Distance Learning” above the Coronavirus Information tab. This will give you quick access to learning plans, student resources, district announcements and more. Check it out!

Donations: The Bismarck Public Schools Foundation (BPSF) has established a COVID-19 BPS Family Assistance Fund. Those that wish to donate may do so through the foundation website or by mail. To donate online, go to https://www.bpsfoundation.com/donate/ and click “COVID-19 BPS Family Assistance.” To donate by mail, send checks to the BPS Foundation at 806 N. Washington St., Bismarck, ND 58501 and write “COVID-19” in the memo line. Families seeking assistance are encouraged to reach out to their counselor or social worker who will connect them to established community resources as well as submit requests for funding needs that cannot be met within existing resources. The BPSF thanks those who have already reached out to volunteer and/or provide monetary donations to help those within our community who are struggling.

Getting Home Internet: BPS provided a list of potential providers. We know it is difficult to get in touch with some given the demands right now. We encourage you to keep trying and continue to use the off-line learning options e-mailed to you Sunday and listed under the new orange Distance Learning icon. Items in Lockers/Desks: Each of our K-12 schools will contact its parents for a time to get items essential to learning out of lockers and desks. This would include Chromebooks and musical instruments, for example.

Park and Learn: BPS has increased our bandwidth so students/families without internet can use our drive-up “park and learn” option from outside all BPS buildings. Our network names are “BPS-Student” on a Chromebook or “BPS-Guest”. Similar options in the community include:
Parking lots at Capital Ice Complex, BSC Aquatic and Wellness Center, Pebble Creek/Fore Seasons Center, and New Generations Park.
General Sibley Park and Campground (between the office).

Prom: Legacy High School has postponed prom for now. It was supposed to take place April 4. Decisions about proms at BHS and CHS will be made later as we are making decisions on events week-by-week. Special Education: Case workers are reaching out to all 1,700+ families via phone or email this week to answer questions and address any concerns.

div.h1: Tuesday, March 24 letter to Class of 2020

div.p: Dear BPS Senior Class of 2020,

I think during these strange and uncertain times, it is ever more important for us to stay connected. So, let me briefly introduce myself Class of 2020: My name is Dr. Ben Johnson, and I’m the Assistant Superintendent of Secondary Schools at BPS (middle & high schools). Prior to me being an assistant superintendent, I had the pleasure of teaching and then serving as assistant principal and principal at the high school level. I’m married to a school psychologist who works at the elementary level, and I have two daughters who are both making big transitions this spring as they move up to middle school and high school in the fall. To say that they are both worried and frustrated that their last spring at elementary and middle school was full of disruption and confusion is a huge understatement.

I do not think that any of you believed that the spring of your senior year would bring so much disruption to what should have been some of the happiest moments of your high school years. It was going to be the last of many things: spring sports, academic and sports banquets, music and theatre performances, capstone projects, club gatherings, and yes, prom. All of these moments building up to that final walk across the stage to claim the diploma you have worked so hard for during your time at BPS. Whether you are a Demon, Patriot, Saber, or Phoenix, you are all experiencing the same disappointment. We want you to know that we are absolutely sharing that disappointment with you. We understand and we hear you.

In order to keep you, your classmates, and the rest of the community safe, BPS is following the Governor’s and Department of Public Instruction’s guidance of suspending school until further notice. There is a lot of unknowns right now with what will happen in the future, and this may elicit confusion, disappointment, and even anger. We at BPS want to assure you that we are doing our very best to make the right decisions that will protect everyone. While at this moment we can’t tell you for sure what will happen to prom and graduation, we want you to know that every decision we make along the way is not taken lightly. We are doing the very best that we can to ensure that these opportunities are preserved, while at the same time maintaining everyone’s safety. Although you still have opportunities to connect with your classmates and your teachers electronically, we know that this is not the same experience that you were looking forward to at the end of your senior year. It’s not what you and the rest of the BPS community deserves. Unfortunately, you and your senior classmates are learning the powerful life lesson that you can’t control what happens to you, but you can control how you respond to it.

While we find every possible way to celebrate your success, we encourage you to finish your senior year strong. COVID-19 may have disrupted your daily life, but you have the power to continue on your senior journey and take ownership of the post-secondary path that you’ve chosen, whether it’s college, military service, or entering the workforce. These disruptions may seem like stumbling blocks, but it’s how you respond that shapes these stumbling blocks into stepping stones towards your future. In the meanwhile, we are here for you. Your building’s administration, teachers, staff, and counselors are here to provide support along the way as we navigate this together. Despite the distance, we will all continue to build upon the relationships we have built along the way.
We look forward to calling each of you proud BPS alumni. The world is waiting for you, Class of 2020!
Dr. Ben Johnson
Assistant Superintendent for Secondary Schools

We hope this balmy Monday finds you well. Take the kids, go for a walk and see if you can find any hearts to count in local windows. You can learn about this COVID craze at https://www.facebook.com/groups/aworldofhearts/?ref=share! We only have a few new things to share today. We hope these district updates will get shorter as schools now will be communicating more with students, parents and staff.

ul.li: Assessment Guidelines: All statewide assessments have been cancelled for the year. This includes the NDSA, NDAA, and the ACT. More information will be coming soon regarding the ACT test for juniors who did not take the test on the initial date.

Camp Edventure: The registration period for elementary Camp Ed summer school has been extended! Go to https://www.bismarckschools.org/ under District Announcements, download the document, fill it out, and mail or e-mail it to your child’s school.

Computer Distribution: If high school students didn’t get their Chromebooks last week, they should contact their school. Middle school is having a 2nd distribution tomorrow and Wednesday. Go to your e-mail or your school’s website under District Announcements for instructions. Each elementary principals will communicate this week with their parents regarding getting computers, etc.

Child Nutrition: We served just shy of 2,600 to-go meals today. There are now 12 school sites: BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln, Moses, Myhre, Pioneer, Sunrise, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. The hours are Monday-Friday, 11:30 am-12:30 pm.

School Board Brief: The School Board’s regularly scheduled meeting was held via conference call tonight. The meeting was not broadcast but here the main things that were discussed. The Board received an update from the Superintendent on what the district and schools have been communicating to staff and parents regarding the COVID-19 pandemic. Superintendent Hornbacher said, “Everything we do is built on relationships; there has been an outpouring of staff and community members offering to help.” Board members expressed appreciation and thanks to students, parents and staff who have been so wonderful during this crisis. Board members also accepted the annual academic achievement report on Science as making reasonable progress. You can view that report on the March 23 school board agenda: https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/401

Survey: Last chance to complete the 2-minute annual School Board survey relating to school district direction/goals and communication. Deadline is Tuesday, 3/24, at 5 pm: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/8N58FL6

div.h1: Monday, March 23 to middle school families

div.p: Middle school families will have a second opportunity to access student Chromebooks, if needed. If families have adequate home devices we ask that you please NOT take a BPS device.
All three middle schools will be distributing from HUGHES Education Center (806 N. Washington - parking lot).

p.strong:
Tuesday, March 24, 3-5:30 pm
Wednesday, March 25, 10 am-2 pm

div.p: There will be three buses. One per school and they will be signed. Do NOT get out of your vehicle. You will pull up and the Chromebook will be retrieved for you. In order to speed up the process, please know your student’s home base teacher’s name prior to arriving. Students will receive their specifically issued device and will continue to be responsible for it at home. Students do not need to be present to pick up the device.

NOTE: Chromebooks were collected from homerooms, so if the Chromebook was NOT in their homeroom (such as in a locker, etc.), you will NOT be able to access the device at this time. You will need to contact your child’s school directly. Thanks!

Below are links to instructions for student learning March 23-27. Our intent is to move to distance learning the week of March 30. BPS will be reaching out to parents and students regarding this early this week. If you have questions, contact your child's school's main phone number (https://www.bismarckschools.org/phone) starting at 10 am on Monday, March 23. Thanks!
Elementary

Though BPS students have only technically had no school for four days due to COVID-19, it seems much longer. You are probably feeling that, too. As the weekend approaches and you are healthy, go outside for a walk, play a family board game or put together a puzzle. Maybe take a break from the news during the day. Parents Lead has some great resources for talking to kids of all ages about Coronavirus—even older students who are upset that their fine arts, sports and other activities have been cancelled or put on hold. Check out http://www.parentslead.org/COVID-19. Stay safe and stay connected. We will send more messages this weekend, if needed.

ul.li: Academics: Our plan is to allow teachers and other educational staff to get their classroom plans finalized next week and officially begin teaching students again the week of March 30. This will also allow us time to “get the bugs out” as we move to distance learning. Staff, parents and students may have technical issues that need to be dealt with. More information to come!

Activities: Click here for information from the ND High School Activities Association regarding spring practices: https://www.bismarckschools.org/cms/lib/ND02203833/Centricity/Domain/832/COVID-19%20Spring%20Practices%20NDHSAA.pdf
Central Office: Essential staff are still meeting at Central Office. Inner school and outside mail and printing will be delivered to schools starting Monday.
School Phones: The main number for each school will be staffed starting next week. Here is the BPS phone directory listed at the bottom of our webpage: https://www.bismarckschools.org/phone

Computers & Internet: BPS is working to provide access to district devices for K-12 families. Additional messages and plans for accessing a device will be coming soon. We understand that having a device without having Internet has limited functionality. Plans for distance learning include both online and off-line options. BPS has enabled drive-up (Park & Learn) Internet access near all school district buildings. Our network names are “BPS-Student” on a Chromebook or “BPS-Guest”. If you use the Park & Learn option, you must practice the advised safe social distancing of 6 feet from other users. Additional information on Internet and Device Access is available at https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/3813

Musical Instruments & Other Items: We hope to set up distribution times for students/parents to receive these items next week. Students do not need to “clean out their lockers or desks” but if there are items you need, including student medication, we will make those available. Watch for details to come from your school instead of the district office.

Child Nutrition: BPS is adding Pioneer and Sunrise Elementary Schools as sites starting next week. At those 2 sites the meals will be served out of school buses. The other sites are at BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Lincoln School (not the Cenex area) Moses, Myhre, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, and South Central. The hours are Mon.-Fri., 11:30 am-12:30 pm. BPS gave out 2,600 total meals (NOTE: we did NOT double what we have been delivering; we just want to be consistent with the way other districts are reporting, so today it was 1,300 breakfasts and 1,300 lunches for a total of 2,600.

div.p: Have a great weekend! We may not send anything Saturday but we plan to send a BPS update on Sunday after lunch.

Working together, we can slow the spread of COVID-19. Based on Governor Burgum’s address today, Bismarck Public Schools has now decided not to have school from Monday, March 23 through Tuesday, March 31. We know that school cancellation is a burden on families, but we do this out of love and protection for our children, parents, staff and community.
School Days off Waived: Governor Burgum will waive all days off through March 31.
Academics: Tomorrow, we will give guidance to students/parents and teachers for next week. Staff will also receive guidance from the BPS Human Resources (HR) Department.

Computers: We plan to allow for at-home use of district computers (Chromebooks). BPS will provide multiple opportunities for device checkout and pickup in each scenario so we ask for patience as plans are finalized.

ul.li: Grades 9-12: All BHS, CHS, and LHS students were previously issued a device.
SCHS students and any other high school students who did not take their device home will be made aware of options to pick them up next week.
Grades 6-8: A separate message will go out tonight to middle school parents about a FIRST opportunity to pick up a device for BPS middle school students tomorrow, Friday, March 20.
Grades PreK-5: Plans are being formulated. Expect future communications.

Backpack for Kids on Friday: Students or parents of students in need who regularly receive food backpacks on Fridays to take home for the weekend can pick them up at the same time and places we will deliver daily to-go breakfast & lunch bags tomorrow: 11:30 am-12:30 pm at BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Moses, Myhre, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS, South Central, and the Cenex Station roundabout in Lincoln.
Child Nutrition: Today, BPS gave out nearly 1,100 go bags at the times and locations listed above.

Students in Transition: If you are in the SIT program for homeless youth and you are experiencing problems while schools are closed, you can call or text program coordinator Sherrice Roness at 701-527-4927 from 8 am to 4 pm. Please leave a voice message.

div.p: Bismarck Public Schools will be canceling school in all PreK-12 buildings for the week of March 23rd through March 27th due to the ongoing spread of Coronavirus in the state of North Dakota. The growing number of positive cases in the Bismarck-Mandan community is a substantial factor in this decision to help avoid further community spread. And decisions beyond March 27th will be made at a later date.

Bismarck Public Schools believes this proactive approach is in the best interest of our families and this community, specifically the most vulnerable at-risk populations such as the elderly and medically fragile. Bismarck Public Schools will continue to work with and seek guidance from local and state officials as we develop plans for a long term solution in these unprecedented times.

Bismarck Public Schools will release guidance for students, staff, and our parents by Friday evening, March 20th. Next week, Bismarck Public School District staff will further develop our Distance Learning Plan which will be used to provide direction and guidance throughout all Bismarck Schools.
Thank you for our continued support and understanding. The safety of our students, staff and community is our number one concern.
Watch for our daily update today to be sent via e-mail and text in the late afternoon or early evening.

Governor Doug Burgum stated today that our Focus is on Facts, not Fear. When people are afraid, they go into panic mode or denial. Facts will help us move to a more calm state. As BPS has facts to share, we will do so in a responsible, caring manner.
Here is today’s update on BPS Coronavirus planning & questions:

ul.li: Classes: BPS schools are still closed through Friday, March 20. We have received no guidance yet on whether schools will be closed after that date. We will let you know as soon as we know. Enjoy this time with your children and family.

Q3 Middle/High School Grades: Quarter 3 grades will not be “closed” until further notice. This will give our grades 6-12 staff and students some breathing room to get work accomplished at a later time. To further reinforce, there should be no new assignments at this time; students should be completing work previously assigned.

Food Donations: BPS has had many kind offers to help with student feeding. Individuals: if you want to make a monetary donation to help feed students in need, go to https://www.bismarckschools.org/Page/3381 and follow the instructions listed. If you are not a MyPaymentsPlus user, you will need to set up an account. Businesses: if you wish to make a monetary donation for food, go here: https://www.bpsfoundation.com/donate/. If you wish to make a different kind of donation, e-mail stacey_lang@bismarckschools.org with the BPS Foundation.

Child Nutrition: We served nearly 900 meals again today. BPS will continue to provide breakfast/lunch to go-bags for any child ages 1-18 regardless of which school they attend. They can be picked up tomorrow & Friday from 11:30 am-12:30 pm at the front door OR parking lot at: BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Moses, Myhre, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS and South Central. Meals will also be offered at the Cenex roundabout in Lincoln.

Backpack for Kids program on Friday from 11:30-12:30: Students or parents of students in need who regularly receive food backpacks on Fridays to take home for the weekend can pick them up at the above locations.

For Verizon Users ONLY: if you are a Verizon user and you are trying to call 701-323-4000 with an emergency question, you are not able to get through at this time. Until this issue is resolved, please e-mail contactus@bismarckschools.org. We ask that you use this phone number and e-mail for important issues only as we have limited staff available to reply.

Communication: BPS intends to send at least one update to parents/staff each day Monday-Friday late in the afternoon or early evening, and weekends if necessary. If our SwiftK-12 email, text and phone notification system would go down for any reason, check our website for these updates. We will also ask local news media to help us inform you of any BPS auto-notification issues.

Family/Staff Wellness: Our website has a couple of good resources on how to talk to kids about COVID-19. It’s under the Coronavirus tab on the right; scroll down to the bottom of Additional Resources; our BPS Parent & Staff Wellness Brochure is also posted here on the right.
English Learners: BPS has posted CDC resources on Coronavirus in different languages for our non-English speaking families. Go to our Coronavirus link under Centers for Disease Control on the right.
Camp Ed & Middle School Summer School: Please mail forms to the school office where your child would attend these summer programs. Thanks!

Census: BPS is a major player in the 2020 Census effort! The US Census Bureau is mailing notifications to homes this week with detailed information on how to take the 2020 Census. The following link is now live with the option for residents to take the Census online at https://2020census.gov/. Anyone can use this site to complete their Census, even if you have not received a postcard & 12-digit ID number! You can get a number online to quickly and easily complete the Census.

div.p: In our continued efforts to communicate with you during the Coronavirus situation, we have a few updates for today; some are based on calls we received at 701-323-4000.

ul.li: Days off forgiven: The Governor last night announced that K-12 schools who are closed this week do not have to make up the instructional time later this school year.

Child Nutrition: Today’s food distribution went well; we gave out 759 go-bags. BPS will continue to provide breakfast/lunch to go-bags for any child ages 1-18 regardless of which school they attend, public or private. They can be picked up daily through Friday from 11:30 am-12:30 pm at the front door OR parking lot at: BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Moses, Myhre, Will-Moore, Wachter, BHS, CHS and South Central. Meals will also be offered at the Cenex Gas Station roundabout in Lincoln. Students will not be allowed into the building to eat their meal.

Backpack for Kids program: For students who regularly receive food backpacks on Fridays to take home for the weekend, we have coordinated with United Way & Community Action so these can be picked up by students or parents at the above locations on Friday, March 20, 11:30 am-12:30 pm.

Student Medications: Parents who have student medication at school should have received a call today in case they need the medication at home. School nurses are making arrangements for those parents to pick up medications at school on Wednesday, March 18, or to have the medications delivered to them if they do not have transportation. This is the only student item that can be retrieved from schools this week.
Camp Ed & middle school summer school: The deadline for registering is this week. If you haven’t gotten your paperwork in yet, please mail it. We will be flexible on the postmark date!

Family/Staff Wellness: BPS is working with community partners to ensure the basic needs of our students, families, and staff are met. Many community agencies are prepared to support all of us in meeting these needs. Information is also provided to obtain ongoing support with food, clothing, and behavioral/mental health. Tips for managing stress are also included in this resource. The brochure offers reliable resources to obtain accurate information regarding COVID-19.
Frequently Asked Questions: BPS has created an FAQ based on questions we are receiving during the Coronavirus.

p.em: Here is an update of the work our administrative teams completed today. Please watch your e-mails daily as we will provide more information as it becomes available in this rapidly-changing Coronavirus environment. Because schools are closed this week, there will be no staff in our buildings to answer questions. If you have an emergency question, please call the district administrative office at 701-323-4000 during normal working hours Monday-Friday. If the line is busy or no one answers, leave a message and we will get back to you as soon as we can.

div.p: Homework: There is no homework this week for BPS students as school was cancelled. We are working on plans for e-learning in the future, if we need them. Guidance will be provided to teachers later this week and to parents next week, again, only if needed.

Child Nutrition: BPS recognizes that many students rely on school meals during the day and we will continue to offer a limited breakfast and lunch menu during the school closure. Starting tomorrow, Tuesday, March 17, BPS will provide free meals for ANY child ages 1-18 regardless of which school they attend, public or private. A to-go bag which will include lunch for that day and breakfast for the next morning, can be picked up by parent or student from 11:30 am-12:30 pm EACH DAY, Monday through Friday, at the front door or by the parking lot of these schools: BECEP at Richholt, Grimsrud, Moses, Myhre, Will-Moore, Wachter Middle School, Bismarck High, Century High, and South Central High School. Meals will also be offered at the Cenex Gas Station roundabout in Lincoln. Students will not be allowed into the building to eat their meal. We are also in communication with the weekend Backpack for Kids program for students in need which is run by United Way and Community Action. We will let you know if we come up with a plan to distribute those backpacks to designated students Friday, March 20.

Student Medications: At the elementary level, nurses will be at each school on Wednesday, March 18. Nurses will call or email parents regarding medication that is kept at school for their child. If parents need the medication, they can make arrangements to pick it up. If a parent doesn’t have transportation, a nurse will deliver it to their home or workplace. Our head school nurse will do the same thing for parents of middle and high school students who have medication at school. NOTE: students and parents will not be let into schools this week to retrieve any other items.

p.em: We cannot repeat enough that we appreciate how you are handling this situation. We have had an outpouring of support and we are truly grateful of your care for our children, families, school staff and community. Thank you. Together, we will weather this situation with grace and civility.

div.p: Dear Parents/Guardians & Staff,

Thank you for your patience as we work though this unprecedented situation. Bismarck Public Schools continues to work in tandem with local, state and national officials regarding the Coronavirus (COVID-19). We are trying to do our part to protect our community and the most susceptible, our elderly and medically fragile populations. We will continue to provide updates as we determine processes and procedures. Here is an update for the past 18 hours:
Monday, March 16, 2020:

ul.li: EOP: BPS has updated our Emergency Operations Plan regarding Pandemics/Epidemics with our school administrators.
Deep Cleaning: This week the emphasis for our custodial staff will be to ensure that we have conducted proper sanitizing and deep cleaning of all buildings.

Activities: BPS has suspended all after-school activities for this week. This includes athletics, practices, contests, school concerts, Parks and Recreation activities in our facilities, and activities of those who rent our facilities. No internal or external group may us BPS facilities including the Career Academy.
Community Facility Planning Meetings: These community meetings which had been scheduled for March will be rescheduled after April 1, 2020.

Busing: Harlow’s and Bismarck Public Schools have plans in place for routine sanitation for all buses. The BPS Transportation Department is cleaning and disinfecting our entire fleet of buses, cars, and vans. Our drivers and bus monitors will be asked to wipe down hand rails and common touch areas at the end of each route.

Communication: BPS is communicating using its Emergency Notification System called SwiftK-12. When we plan to cancel or open school, we will use the telephone feature. Otherwise we intend to communicate via email and/or text. If you know a parent who is not getting these communications, share information with them or direct them to on our website at https://www.bismarckschools.org/covid-19. At this time, there are no school secretaries in the buildings to help parents update their emergency information or set up a PowerSchool account to communicate with their teacher(s).

STAFF: Pre-K & Special Education only: Email guidance for all Special Ed and Early Childhood Special Education staff will come from Danica Nelson. Email for all Head Start and Early Head Start will come from Laurel Pickard. Emails for Right Track and Early Intervention staff will come from Val Bakken.

This Week: BPS continues to plan around the following topics and will communicate with staff and the community later today and throughout the week. We ask everyone to exercise patience during this time. Teachers have been asked to wait for BPS guidance prior to sending school work and items to parents. Here is what BPS is working on:
Academics & E-Learning (this includes the deployment of student computers)
Special Education & English Language Interventions
Child Nutrition (breakfast & lunch to students)
Activities
Student Medications (how to get them from the school)
Continued Cleaning (buildings, buses)
Potential Child Care for 1st responders & medical personnel
BPS Employee Work, Pay & Wellness (this includes possible staff training opportunities)
Student/Family Wellness
Future Professional Development and supports for all staff
Communications

div.p: We hope to send more information later today after our teams have had a chance to meet and discuss the above issues.

Parents/Guardians: The governor has directed all K-12 schools in North Dakota to close this week. Bismarck Public Schools (including BECEP & Head Start) will be closed through Friday, March 20. We will send more information to families tomorrow. Information is posted online at https://www.bismarckschools.org/covid-19, including how to talk with children about Coronavirus. We appreciate your patience and understanding during this rapidly-changing situation.

Staff: The governor has directed all K-12 schools in North Dakota to close this week. Bismarck Public Schools (including BECEP & Head Start) will be closed through Friday, March 20. There will be no Staff Development tomorrow. Only essential personnel will report on Monday and Tuesday. This means principals, assistant principals, instructional coaches, library media specialists, and custodians will report to their buildings at 8 am. Tomorrow, we will send more information to answer staff questions.

ul.li: BPS Attendance/Test Exemption: Parents always have the prerogative to keep their children home, especially if they are medically fragile. Effective March 17, absences which are medically excused or excused by a parent due to a child illness will not count as a factor for attendance or the high school test exemption policy.

BPS Travel: BPS is suspending school sponsored international and out–of-state travel for students until further notice. There will also be no school-sponsored out-of-state travel for staff through the end of March.

Activities: The ND High School Activities Association (NDHSAA) has indefinitely suspended Class A & B Basketball State Tournaments, in addition to NDHSAA fine arts and the spring sports seasons, practices and games/contests.

p.span: Two email updates were sent to all parents and staff. Also, BPS Superintendent Jason Hornbacher, as well as BPS safety and custodial staff, attended meetings with Bismarck State College regarding their plans to deal with COVID-19. Please see
TO: Our parents, staff and community

div.p: Dear Members of the Bismarck Public Schools Community,

As you know from previous communications and our posting to the BPS Webpage, Bismarck Public Schools is closely monitoring events and public health recommendations surrounding the outbreak and spread of the Coronavirus (COVID-19). The health of our students, staff and community is our top priority. There is an escalated response to this within our community, state and beyond.
The first case of COVID-19 in North Dakota was confirmed last night. Even though it was diagnosed in a distant part of the state it merits our attention and careful consideration. As this week draws to a close and we enter a long weekend here is some additional information:

ol.li: Please remember this is simply an update as of 2:30 p.m. on 3/12/2020 and any and all of this information could change at a moment’s notice.
Bismarck Public Schools continues to follow State Health Department and CDC guidance. This is posted at https://www.bismarckschools.org/.
Bismarck Public Schools Central Office continues to meet twice daily to track progress of this issue and plan for an outbreak.
Bismarck Public Schools encourages sick students and staff to stay home.
Bismarck Public Schools is working in conjunction with BSC, U of Mary, UTTC, DPI, the State Health Department, the Governor’s Office and Mandan Public Schools.

NDSU, UND, and some smaller universities are extending the spring break and/or moving to an on-line platform for student classes. It is important to note that K-12 and the University system are both educational institutions but serve different clients and the impact on closing down have very different impacts to a community. I caution all that the assumption that K-12 should shut down because Higher Education has, could create community issues beyond the educational setting.
COVID-19 appears to pose the greatest risk to older adults and those with underlying and chronic health conditions.

All student and staff travel out of state is being considered on a case-by-case basis as per State Health Department/CDC Guidelines. BPS only has one trip on the books for the remainder of March and this trip is being evaluated in conjunction with the school administrator.
Bismarck Public Schools has all the safety materials and supplies available to respond to an outbreak.
Staff development from March 17 through March 30 is being reviewed and may be rescheduled for a later date.
Bismarck Public Schools is reviewing the Attendance Policy and intends to establish and provide guidelines by 3/16/2020.
NDHSAA will continue scheduled events as of 2:00 p.m. 3/12/2020

If schools are closed for an extended period of time the following is developed or being developed:
a. Pre-K-12 protocols and procedures for students to continue their academics at home are being developed.
b. BPS is reviewing protocol to determine staff needs and the ability to work in an on-line environment.
c. BPS is determining the ability to provide meals to students.
d. BPS has plans to address essential staff needed within buildings.

div.p: Bismarck Public Schools will continue to post information to our website and no later than Monday, 3/16/2020 an additional posting will be made to staff and parents. This new and difficult situation should not paralyze us as we work and learn in this great community. Each of us can do our part by taking care of ourselves, others and adhering to the CDC preventative measures.

Respectfully,
Dr. Jason Hornbacher, Superintendent
Bismarck Public Schools
(701) 323-4054

p.span: ND High School Activities Association communicates regularly with NDDoH. At this time Class A State Basketball will be held.

BPS administrative staff took part in a ND Dept. of Health (NDDoH) update on the spread of the Coronavirus. BPS administration started daily planning meetings regarding COVID-19. Curtailing travel involving BPS students and staff will be decided on a case-by-case basis.
BPS asked principals to remind staff to tell students to wash their hands frequently. Custodians have been using cleaning precautions like they do during the annual flu season.
BPS posted a letter from our Superintendent on our response, as well as other coronavirus information, on our website under Quick Links. An email was sent to all parents & staff.

div.p:
TO: Our parents, staff and community
FR: Bismarck Public Schools
DA: Wednesday, March 4, 2020

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has provided guidance for schools to plan, prepare, and respond to coronavirus (COVID-19). Working together with state and local health departments, we all have an important role in slowing the spread of diseases to help ensure safe and healthy learning environments.

While the risk to those living in the U.S. remains low, we want you to know that BPS is monitoring the situation, and we are planning our response to the health and academic needs of students in case of an outbreak.
The guidance we have received from the ND Department of Health is as follows:

ul.li: wash hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds;
avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands;
cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue and throw it away;
clean and disinfect frequently-touched surfaces/objects regularly;
get plenty of rest, drink fluids, and eat healthy foods;
avoid close contact with people who are sick;
and stay home when you are sick.

div.p: Bismarck Public Schools stresses these same things with students each year during normal cold and flu season, and we ask that you continue to reinforce this at home.

Symptoms of the COVID-19 include fever, cough and shortness of breath. The symptoms may appear in as few as two days or as long as 14 days after exposure. If you develop symptoms, please call your health provider and tell them about your recent travel or exposure.

Bismarck Public Schools takes the safety of our students and staff very seriously. We will continue to monitor the situation, work with state and local health officials, and follow recommended guidance as it becomes available. We have posted coronavirus information on our BPS website at www.bismarckschools.org under Quick Links.
Thank you for your attention to this matter. If you have questions, contact our school nurse supervisor Kate Gartner, 701-323-4024, kate_gartner@bismarckschools.org.

Sincerely,
Dr. Jason Hornbacher, Superintendent

CDC released guidance to U.S. schools; BPS reviewed the information.
